collection.description: The Konstantin Stanislavsky Correspondence is a small archive consisting of handwritten letters and some telegrams Stanislavsky sent to Elizabeth Hapgood, the translator of his works into English between 1928 and 1936. The letters deal with a wide array of subjects: work on various theoretical books Stanislavsky was composing, his constant work in theatre and opera, travel, personal and familial matters, and obliquely, Soviet politics.
collection.title: Konstantin Stanislavsky Correspondence

scope_and_contents.item: The archive is comprised of ~65 handwritten letters from Stanislavskii to Elizabeth Hapgood, 6 telegrams and 3 typed letters. The correspondence ranges from 1928 to 1936 and concerns Stanislavskii’s thoughts on art, his acting studios and workshops, various dramatic and operatic productions, especially Dead Souls and The Golden Cockerel, the fates of various writers and artists he has known, European and American political affairs in the interim between the Wars, and personal reminiscences.

collection.description: The Konstantin Stanislavsky Correspondence is a small archive consisting of handwritten letters and some telegrams Stanislavsky sent to Elizabeth Hapgood, the translator of his works into English between 1928 and 1936. The letters deal with a wide array of subjects: work on various theoretical books Stanislavsky was composing, his constant work in theatre and opera, travel, personal and familial matters, and obliquely, Soviet politics.
collection.title: Konstantin Stanislavsky Correspondence
